text:
Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com. Razumihin will find me. Better to just bail… go far away… to America, and let them deal with it! And grab the IOU… that might come in handy there. What else should I take? They think I’m sick! They have no clue I can walk, ha-ha-ha! I could see it in their eyes—they know something! If only I could get downstairs! What if they have cops waiting down there? 

What’s this tea? Oh, and there’s some beer left, half a bottle, cold! 🍺  
He grabbed the bottle, downed the last bit of beer like it was the best thing ever, as if it could put out a fire inside him. But soon, the beer hit him, and a nice, tingly feeling ran down his spine. He lay back, pulled the quilt over himself, and his jumbled thoughts started to drift apart. Before long, he felt a light, cozy drowsiness wash over him. Snuggling into the pillow, he wrapped himself tighter in the soft quilt that replaced his old, ragged coat, sighed softly, and slipped into a deep, refreshing sleep. 

He woke up to someone coming in. He opened his eyes and saw Razumihin in the doorway, unsure if he should come in or not. Raskolnikov sat up quickly on the sofa, trying to remember something.  
“Ah, you’re awake! Here I am! Nastasya, bring in the parcel!” Razumihin called down the stairs. “You’ll get the account soon.”  
“What time is it?” Raskolnikov asked, looking around nervously.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov, feeling ill and disoriented, contemplates escaping while experiencing a mix of discomfort and drowsiness before falling into a deep sleep.
